item.title: Decryption Challenge
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:16, topic:406636”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=503636.msg3686583#msg3686583 date=1311887769]
Lawl not butt hurt, just lost my cool. I lost my ways of not letting people get the best of me.

Oh lawl, see if you said this earlier we would have avoided conflict.

keys[i] |= (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8); // notice the "|=" rather than "="

Thanks for the fix, I have no idea why I missed that. You had no discussion on the actual math, so I assumed you were another flaming idiot.
[/quote]
Err I had mentioned you were reassigning. See if you didn’t have such a big ego, we would have avoided conflict.[/quote]

Ego? Nah don’t have much ego sir. Must have missed that piece…people being blunt to me is one of my weaknesses. Erm didn’t think of using a 128 bit, mainly because I couldn’t find a good 128 bit hash. I liked SHA so I just went with it, it works perfectly in my opinion.

item.title: Decryption Challenge
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:14, topic:406636”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=503636.msg3686527#msg3686527 date=1311885135]
No I am taking a byte from the digest, then shifting it by a multiple of 8 depending on this loop.

From here you can obviously see that the current key (denoted by i) is to be set by 4 digest bytes using the counter variable to get the correct byte from the digest.
[/quote]
You are reassigning (why don’t you understand…), so it doesn’t matter what you did before in the loop. What you want to be doing is

keys[i] |= (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8); // notice the "|=" rather than "="

You. Are. Fucking. Retarded.

The reason I used the SHA-512 is that it has a fixed output digest of, take a gander 64 bytes. Although there should be 16 keys, I used 8 to test some properties of the encryption. Another thing, its a ‘modified’ XTEA because the digest length; is again, 64 bytes. It would be a waste to just use the first 16 or possibly the first 32. I have a later version and as of now I use all of the 64 bytes to form the 16 integer keys.

Uhmm why not generate a 128-bit key then? Ditch SHA-512 and use something that is actually for key generation.

Now lets talk about how you don’t understand why the keys are integers, you obviously have no knowledge on XTEA. Each KEY is a 32 bit integer, each calculation requires 4 but in this case I make it so it is 8 and in the new version it is 16. The purpose of the SHA-512 digest to randomize the keys. Because the SHA-512 does not follow a pattern (avalanche effect) when the password changes the data will also follow the avalanche effect. This has been proven with some experiments, don’t even question it because I will have another post like this. Now, do some research and actually figure out what you are talking about before you post, because that was a waste of my time to explain how this works.

What makes you think I don’t understand why the keys are integers? No faggot fuck, there is only one key, which the int array makes up.

Get off your high horse. You’re an idiot as far as I’m concerned.

You’re not worth fighting with. Some advice; when you do not understand the topic I suggest you don’t try and act like you do.

OH LOL I DIDN’T SEE THIS. WHY SO BUTTHURT???[/quote]

Lawl not butt hurt, just lost my cool. I lost my ways of not letting people get the best of me.

Oh lawl, see if you said this earlier we would have avoided conflict.

keys[i] |= (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8); // notice the "|=" rather than "="

Thanks for the fix, I have no idea why I missed that. You had no discussion on the actual math, so I assumed you were another flaming idiot. Fixed that bug, and 1 key? Don’t get.

Read full topic

item.title: Decryption Challenge
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:13, topic:406636”]Huh? Okay buddy before you make the same mistake again; and S1gma stay out of this,

No I am taking a byte from the digest, then shifting it by a multiple of 8 depending on this loop.

From here you can obviously see that the current key (denoted by i) is to be set by 4 digest bytes using the counter variable to get the correct byte from the digest.

DUUUHHHHH

for(int j = 0; j < 4; j++) {

This just sets the counter to the correct position within the digest array to make sure the key follows the correct order.

counter = i * 4;

You. Are. Fucking. Retarded.

keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8); [/quote]
You are reassigning (why don’t you understand…), so it doesn’t matter what you did before in the loop. What you want to be doing is

keys[i] |= (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8); // notice the "|=" rather than "="

You. Are. Fucking. Retarded.

sinisoul:

The reason I used the SHA-512 is that it has a fixed output digest of, take a gander 64 bytes. Although there should be 16 keys, I used 8 to test some properties of the encryption. Another thing, its a ‘modified’ XTEA because the digest length; is again, 64 bytes. It would be a waste to just use the first 16 or possibly the first 32. I have a later version and as of now I use all of the 64 bytes to form the 16 integer keys.

Uhmm why not generate a 128-bit key then? Ditch SHA-512 and use something that is actually for key generation.

sinisoul:

Now lets talk about how you don’t understand why the keys are integers, you obviously have no knowledge on XTEA. Each KEY is a 32 bit integer, each calculation requires 4 but in this case I make it so it is 8 and in the new version it is 16. The purpose of the SHA-512 digest to randomize the keys. Because the SHA-512 does not follow a pattern (avalanche effect) when the password changes the data will also follow the avalanche effect. This has been proven with some experiments, don’t even question it because I will have another post like this. Now, do some research and actually figure out what you are talking about before you post, because that was a waste of my time to explain how this works.

What makes you think I don’t understand why the keys are integers? No faggot fuck, there is only one key, which the int array makes up.

Get off your high horse. You’re an idiot as far as I’m concerned.

sinisoul:

You’re not worth fighting with. Some advice; when you do not understand the topic I suggest you don’t try and act like you do.

OH LOL I DIDN’T SEE THIS. WHY SO BUTTHURT???

Read full topic

item.title: Decryption Challenge
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Oh wow, I thought all you needed was a heads up to realise how stupid this is.

I’ll admit, I made a little mistake. This is more like it:

keys[i] = (int) digest[counter += 3] << (3 * 8);

There’s more than one reason why this is fucktarded, but here’s what I was originally saying: There’s no reason to be looping through when this is all it’s doing (you’re REASSIGNING, so whatever you did before to the key doesn’t affect it). You’re taking a byte from the digest and shifting it by 24, so each part of the key can only have its upper 8 bits active. Since each part of the key is effectively 8 bits long, the key is effectively 8*8=64 bits long. Man you are dumb.

Now please, post more stuff so I can wreck your insolent remarks.
Ok well you didn't even address my first point, and I don't know how you can call my remarks insolent like that when your post is full of it. Like I said, the way you're generating the key is retarded. You're creating a SHA-512 digest and taking arbitrary bytes to create the key. Go with one of the more conventional approaches. Also, I don't know why you're using a "modified XTEA". This whole thing is just more complicated than it has to be.

Read full topic

item.title: Decryption Challenge
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:9, topic:406636”] data[i] = (byte) (keys[(i << 1) & 0x7] ^ keys[(i ^ 7) & 0x7] ^ keys[(i >> 1) & 0x7]);
What is this…

for(int j = 0; j < 4; j++)
    if(counter >= digest.length)
        keys[i] = -1 >> (j ^ i);
    else
        keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8);

Has the same effect as

if(counter >= digest.length)
    keys[i] = -1 >> (3 ^ i);
else
    keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (3 * 8);

The key may as well be 64-bits long.

The way you’re generating the key is retarded.[/quote]

Man you are dumb, learn about what I am doing before you post.
Alright now an explanation on why you are stupid:

for(int j = 0; j < 4; j++)
keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8);
keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (3 * 8);

So you don’t understand this is just making a key via the digest? Seriously? How hard is it to understand.

Idiot. Now please, post more stuff so I can wreck your insolent remarks.

Read full topic

item.title: Decryption Challenge
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

data[i] = (byte) (keys[(i << 1) & 0x7] ^ keys[(i ^ 7) & 0x7] ^ keys[(i >> 1) & 0x7]);

What is this…

for(int j = 0; j < 4; j++)
    if(counter >= digest.length)
        keys[i] = -1 >> (j ^ i);
    else
        keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (j * 8);

Has the same effect as

if(counter >= digest.length)
    keys[i] = -1 >> (3 ^ i);
else
    keys[i] = (int) digest[counter++] << (3 * 8);

The key may as well be 64-bits long.

The way you’re generating the key is retarded.

Read full topic
